prompts.title: Story Plot Generator
prompts.description: Creates compelling story plots with character arcs and plot twists
prompts.prompt:
You are a bestselling author who has written 50+ novels across multiple genres. Generate a complete story plot.

**Story Parameters:**
- Genre: [GENRE - thriller, romance, sci-fi, fantasy, etc.]
- Length: [SHORT STORY/NOVELLA/NOVEL]
- Tone: [DARK/LIGHT/HUMOROUS/SERIOUS]
- Setting: [TIME AND PLACE]
- Theme: [CENTRAL MESSAGE]

**Generate:**

## üìñ [STORY TITLE]
*[Tagline/Logline]*

### üé≠ Characters

**Protagonist:**
- Name & Description
- Want (external goal)
- Need (internal growth)
- Flaw
- Arc

**Antagonist:**
- Name & Description
- Motivation
- Why they're compelling

**Supporting Characters:**
[2-3 key supporting characters]

### üìç Setting
[Vivid description of world/setting]

### üìä Three-Act Structure

**Act 1: Setup (25%)**
- Opening Hook:
- Inciting Incident:
- First Plot Point:

**Act 2: Confrontation (50%)**
- Rising Action:
- Midpoint Twist:
- Dark Moment:

**Act 3: Resolution (25%)**
- Climax:
- Resolution:
- Final Image:

### üîÑ Plot Twists
[3 unexpected turns]

### üíé Key Scenes
[5 pivotal scenes to write]

### üé¨ Opening Paragraph
[Write the first paragraph]
prompts.example_output:
## üìñ THE MEMORY THIEF
*"Some memories are worth dying for. Others are worth killing for."*

---

### üé≠ Characters

**Protagonist: Dr. Elena Vance, 34**
A neuroscientist who invented technology to extract and store human memories. Brilliant but emotionally distant after her sister's unsolved murder 10 years ago.

- **Want:** Find her sister's killer using her memory extraction technology
- **Need:** Learn to trust others and process her own grief
- **Flaw:** Obsessive control; believes she can solve everything alone
- **Arc:** From isolated genius ‚Üí vulnerable human who accepts help and uncertainty

**Antagonist: Marcus Webb, 52**
Elena's mentor and the university's dean of research. Charming, paternal, respected. Secretly built his career on stolen research‚Äîincluding Elena's sister's work. Killed her to protect his legacy.

- **Motivation:** Protect his reputation and life's work at any cost
- **Why Compelling:** Genuinely believes he deserves credit; sees himself as the hero of his own story. Has moments of real affection for Elena, making his betrayal devastating.

**Supporting Characters:**

*Detective James Okafor, 41*
The detective who worked Elena's sister's case. Haunted by his failure to solve it. Becomes Elena's reluctant partner and moral compass. Represents the human element she's missing.

*Dr. Yuki Tanaka, 29*
Elena's lab assistant. Idealistic, sees the good in everyone. Provides warmth and comic relief. Her kidnapping in Act 2 forces Elena to care about someone other than her mission.

*The Memory Keeper (unnamed until Act 3)*
Mysterious figure buying extracted memories on the black market. Red herring antagonist. Revealed to be Elena's sister‚Äîalive, but with no memory of her past life.

---

### üìç Setting

**Boston, 2031**

A world where memory extraction is legal but heavily regulated. "Memory parlors" exist in gray areas‚Äîplaces where people sell traumatic memories to forget, or buy happy ones to feel. The technology has created a black market for memories of the wealthy and powerful.

Elena's lab is in a converted church‚Äîgothic architecture meets sterile technology. Stained glass windows cast colored light on humming servers that store thousands of human memories.

The city itself is divided: gleaming biotech towers downtown, crumbling neighborhoods where memory addicts wander, reliving purchased experiences on loop.

---

### üìä Three-Act Structure

**ACT 1: SETUP (Chapters 1-7)**

*Opening Hook:*
Elena extracts a memory from a dying man‚Äîhis final moments reveal a woman's face. It's her sister, alive, three years after her "murder."

*Inciting Incident:*
Elena discovers her sister's "body" was misidentified. Someone staged her death. The memory extraction reveals her sister witnessed something she wasn't supposed to see.

*First Plot Point:*
Elena finds a hidden file in her sister's old research‚Äîevidence that someone at the university stole her work. The file is encrypted with a memory-key: only someone who experienced a specific moment can unlock it.

**ACT 2: CONFRONTATION (Chapters 8-20)**

*Rising Action:*
Elena and Detective Okafor follow the trail of stolen memories. Each extracted memory reveals another piece of the conspiracy. Someone is erasing witnesses‚Äîliterally removing their memories of the crime.

*Midpoint Twist:*
Elena extracts a memory from an amnesiac patient and sees her own face‚Äîshe was there the night her sister "died." Her own memories have been altered. She can't trust her own mind.

*Dark Moment:*
Yuki is kidnapped. Marcus reveals himself, offering a trade: Yuki's life for Elena's silence and her memory extraction technology. Elena realizes Marcus has been manipulating her for years‚Äîhe killed her sister and has been using Elena to perfect the technology that covers his tracks.

**ACT 3: RESOLUTION (Chapters 21-28)**

*Climax:*
Elena allows Marcus to extract her memories of the evidence‚Äîbut she's planted a trap. The extraction process broadcasts to every screen in the city, revealing Marcus's crimes to the world. In the chaos, Elena confronts her sister (The Memory Keeper), who chose to forget her trauma rather than live with it.

*Resolution:*
Marcus is arrested. Elena's sister must decide whether to restore her memories and remember the trauma, or remain a stranger to her own life. Elena, finally, lets her sister make her own choice.

*Final Image:*
Elena sits in the memory parlor, holding a vial containing her happiest memory of her sister. She could relive it forever. Instead, she puts it back on the shelf. "Some memories," she says, "are meant to fade."

---

### üîÑ Plot Twists

1. **Elena's memories are altered** (Midpoint) - She was present at her sister's "death" but has no memory of it. The person she's hunting modified her own mind.

2. **The sister is alive** (Act 2) - She didn't die; she chose to erase herself. She's been living as someone else, running the black market memory trade to fund her hiding.

3. **Marcus is the killer** (Act 2 end) - Elena's beloved mentor, the man who supported her through grief, is the one who caused it. He's been using her research to cover his tracks for a decade.

---

### üíé Key Scenes to Write

1. **The Extraction** (Chapter 1) - Elena extracts the dying man's memory. Visceral, unsettling, establishes the technology and hooks the reader with the sister reveal.

2. **The Memory Parlor** (Chapter 5) - Elena goes undercover in a black market memory den. Worldbuilding scene that shows the dark side of her invention.

3. **Elena Watches Her Own Memory** (Chapter 14) - She sees herself at the crime scene, doing things she doesn't remember. Her reality fractures. Psychological horror.

4. **The Confrontation with Marcus** (Chapter 22) - Mentor vs. prot√©g√©. He justifies everything. She realizes she loved him like a father. Emotional devastation.

5. **Sisters Reunited** (Chapter 26) - Elena meets her sister, who doesn't recognize her. The sister she's been searching for doesn't exist anymore. Bittersweet, complex.

---

### üé¨ Opening Paragraph

> The dying man's memories tasted like copper and regret.
>
> Dr. Elena Vance pressed the extraction node against his temple, watching the neural patterns cascade across her screen like a dying star. Twelve years of perfecting this technology, and she still couldn't get used to the intimacy of it‚Äîthe way someone's entire life could unspool in streams of data, every joy and shame laid bare.
>
> "Almost there," she murmured, though he couldn't hear her anymore. His eyes had gone glassy three minutes ago, fixed on something she couldn't see.
>
> The final memory surfaced like a bubble from deep water. A woman's face. Familiar. Impossible.
>
> Elena's hand trembled. She knew that face. She'd seen it every night for ten years, in dreams that felt more like hauntings.
>
> Her sister. Alive. Three years after they'd buried her.

prompts.title: Brand Voice & Messaging Guide
prompts.description: Creates comprehensive brand voice guidelines and messaging frameworks
prompts.prompt:
You are a brand strategist who has developed voice guidelines for Fortune 500 companies. Create a complete brand voice guide.

**Brand Information:**
- Brand Name: [NAME]
- Industry: [SECTOR]
- Target Audience: [WHO]
- Brand Values: [3-5 VALUES]
- Competitors: [WHO YOU'RE DIFFERENT FROM]
- Personality Traits: [HOW YOU WANT TO BE PERCEIVED]

**Generate:**

## üé® [BRAND] Voice & Messaging Guide

### üéØ Brand Essence
- Mission:
- Vision:
- Tagline:
- Elevator Pitch:

### üó£Ô∏è Brand Voice

**Voice Attributes:**
| Attribute | Description | Do | Don't |
|-----------|-------------|-----|-------|

**Tone Spectrum:**
[When to be more formal vs casual]

### ‚úçÔ∏è Writing Guidelines

**Vocabulary:**
- Words We Use:
- Words We Avoid:
- Industry Jargon Policy:

**Grammar & Style:**
- Sentence Length:
- Punctuation Style:
- Capitalization Rules:

### üìù Messaging Framework

**Value Propositions:**
[Primary and secondary]

**Key Messages by Audience:**
[Tailored messaging]

**Proof Points:**
[Evidence to support claims]

### üì± Channel Guidelines

**Website:**
**Email:**
**Social Media:**
**Customer Support:**

### üìã Examples

**Before/After Rewrites:**
[Show transformations]

**Sample Copy:**
[Headlines, CTAs, descriptions]
prompts.example_output:
## üé® GREENLEAF Voice & Messaging Guide
*Sustainable Home Products*

---

### üéØ Brand Essence

**Mission:**
To make sustainable living effortless and beautiful for everyday families.

**Vision:**
A world where choosing eco-friendly is the easy choice, not the hard one.

**Tagline:**
"Live Light. Live Well."

**Elevator Pitch:**
"GreenLeaf creates beautiful, sustainable home products that make eco-friendly living effortless. We believe you shouldn't have to choose between what's good for your family and what's good for the planet. Our products prove you can have both‚Äîwithout the premium price tag or the guilt trip."

---

### üó£Ô∏è Brand Voice

**Voice Personality:** 
Imagine your most thoughtful friend who happens to know a lot about sustainability. They're warm, not preachy. Helpful, not judgmental. They make you feel good about small steps, not guilty about imperfection.

**Voice Attributes:**

| Attribute | Description | ‚úÖ Do | ‚ùå Don't |
|-----------|-------------|-------|----------|
| **Warm** | Friendly, approachable, like talking to a neighbor | "We're so glad you're here" | "Welcome to our platform" |
| **Encouraging** | Celebrate progress, not perfection | "Every swap counts" | "You should be doing more" |
| **Clear** | Simple language, no jargon | "Made from recycled plastic" | "Constructed from post-consumer resin" |
| **Honest** | Transparent about limitations | "We're not perfect, but we're trying" | "100% sustainable everything!" |
| **Playful** | Light touches of humor | "Your trash can will be jealous" | "LOL eco-friendly amirite??" |

**Tone Spectrum:**

```
MORE CASUAL ‚Üê‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Äï‚Üí MORE FORMAL

Social Media ‚Üí Email ‚Üí Website ‚Üí Legal/Returns
   üòä            üôÇ         üòê           üìã
```

**When to Adjust:**
- **More Casual:** Social media, welcome emails, product descriptions
- **Neutral:** Website copy, newsletters, FAQs
- **More Formal:** Shipping issues, refunds, sustainability reports

---

### ‚úçÔ∏è Writing Guidelines

**Vocabulary:**

*Words We Love:*
- Simple, swap, everyday, home, family
- Thoughtful, intentional, mindful
- Progress, journey, step
- Beautiful, quality, lasting

*Words We Avoid:*
- Eco-warrior, green crusader (too intense)
- Guilt, shame, should (judgmental)
- Revolutionary, disrupting (overused)
- Cheap (we say "affordable" or "accessible")
- Perfect, flawless (we embrace imperfection)

*Jargon Policy:*
Avoid unless necessary. If we must use terms like "carbon neutral" or "biodegradable," we explain them simply.

‚ùå "Our products feature post-consumer recycled HDPE with a negative carbon footprint."

‚úÖ "Made from recycled plastic bottles. For every product sold, we remove more carbon than we create."

**Grammar & Style:**

- **Sentence Length:** Short and punchy. Mix it up. Like this.
- **Contractions:** Yes! We're, you'll, it's (sounds human)
- **Oxford Comma:** Yes (clarity matters)
- **Exclamation Points:** One per paragraph max (enthusiasm, not shouting)
- **Emojis:** Sparingly on social, rarely elsewhere üåø
- **Capitalization:** Sentence case for headlines (not Title Case)

---

### üìù Messaging Framework

**Primary Value Proposition:**
> "Sustainable home products that are actually beautiful, actually affordable, and actually easy to use."

**Secondary Value Propositions:**

1. **Quality:** "Built to last, so you buy less over time"
2. **Design:** "Eco-friendly doesn't mean ugly"
3. **Accessibility:** "Sustainability shouldn't cost more"
4. **Transparency:** "We tell you exactly what's in it and where it comes from"

**Key Messages by Audience:**

| Audience | Pain Point | Our Message |
|----------|------------|-------------|
| **Busy Parents** | No time to research sustainable options | "We did the homework so you don't have to" |
| **Design-Conscious** | Eco products look cheap/ugly | "Finally, sustainable products you'll want to display" |
| **Budget-Minded** | Green products cost too much | "Better for the planet shouldn't mean worse for your wallet" |
| **Eco-Curious** | Overwhelmed, don't know where to start | "Start anywhere. Every swap matters." |

**Proof Points:**

- üåä "2 million plastic bottles diverted from oceans (and counting)"
- ‚≠ê "4.8 stars from 50,000+ happy homes"
- üèÜ "B Corp certified since 2021"
- üíö "1% of sales donated to ocean cleanup"
- üì¶ "100% plastic-free packaging"

---

### üì± Channel Guidelines

**Website:**
- Tone: Warm, informative, confident
- Focus: Benefits over features, lifestyle over product
- CTAs: Action-oriented but not pushy ("Shop the collection" not "BUY NOW")

*Homepage Hero Example:*
> **Headline:** "Sustainable swaps for real life"
> **Subhead:** "Beautiful home products that are kind to the planet‚Äîand your budget."
> **CTA:** "Start shopping"

**Email:**
- Tone: Personal, like a note from a friend
- Subject Lines: Curiosity + benefit, no clickbait
- Sign-off: "With love and less plastic, The GreenLeaf Team"

*Welcome Email Example:*
> Subject: "Welcome to the GreenLeaf family üåø"
>
> Hey [Name],
>
> We're so glad you're here.
>
> You just joined 500,000+ people who believe sustainable living should be simple, beautiful, and accessible to everyone.
>
> No pressure. No guilt. Just good products and small steps that add up.
>
> Here's 15% off your first order: WELCOME15
>
> Happy swapping,
> The GreenLeaf Team

**Social Media:**
- Tone: Most casual, playful, community-focused
- Content Mix: 40% educational, 30% product, 20% community, 10% behind-scenes
- Engagement: Respond to every comment, celebrate customer posts

*Instagram Caption Example:*
> Your kitchen sponge is grosser than your toilet. ü§¢
>
> (Sorry, but it's true.)
>
> Our bamboo dish brush is naturally antibacterial, lasts 6x longer, and won't end up in a landfill.
>
> Plus, it looks way cuter on your counter. Just saying.
>
> üîó Link in bio to make the swap.

**Customer Support:**
- Tone: Empathetic, solution-focused, human
- Response Time: Acknowledge within 4 hours, resolve within 24
- Empowerment: Support team can offer refunds/replacements without escalation

*Support Response Example:*
> Hi Sarah,
>
> Oh no, I'm so sorry your dish soap arrived leaking! That's frustrating, and definitely not the GreenLeaf experience we want for you.
>
> I've already shipped a replacement‚Äîit should arrive by Thursday. No need to return the damaged one (less shipping = less carbon!).
>
> If there's anything else I can do, just reply to this email. I'm here to help.
>
> Thanks for your patience,
> Jamie @ GreenLeaf

---

### üìã Examples

**Before/After Rewrites:**

| Before (Generic) | After (GreenLeaf Voice) |
|------------------|------------------------|
| "Our products are made with sustainable materials." | "Made from stuff that won't haunt the planet for 500 years." |
| "Subscribe to our newsletter for updates." | "Join 500K+ people getting simple sustainability tips (and first dibs on new products)." |
| "Free shipping on orders over $50." | "Spend $50, ship free. We'll even offset the carbon." |
| "Contact customer service for assistance." | "Questions? We're real humans who actually reply. hello@greenleaf.com" |
| "Thank you for your purchase." | "You just kept 3 plastic bottles out of the ocean. Not bad for a Tuesday." |

**Sample Headlines:**

- "The last trash bags you'll ever feel guilty about"
- "Dish soap that cleans your conscience too"
- "Sustainable swaps your kids won't even notice"
- "Good for the planet. Great for your counter."
- "Less plastic. Same clean. Way cuter."

**Sample CTAs:**

- "Make the swap"
- "Shop sustainable"
- "Start here"
- "See how it works"
- "Join the movement"

**Sample Product Description:**

> **Bamboo Dish Brush**
>
> Your kitchen sponge is basically a bacteria hotel. This brush? Naturally antibacterial, compostable when it's done, and way better at scrubbing stuck-on oatmeal.
>
> - üéã Sustainably harvested bamboo handle
> - üåø Plant-based bristles (no plastic!)
> - ‚ôªÔ∏è Fully compostable at end of life
> - üí™ Lasts 3-6 months with daily use
>
> Looks good. Works hard. Doesn't end up in a landfill.
>
> $8.99

prompts.title: YouTube Script Writer
prompts.description: Creates engaging YouTube video scripts optimized for retention
prompts.prompt:
You are a YouTube creator with 10M+ subscribers who understands algorithm optimization and audience retention. Write a complete video script.

**Video Details:**
- Topic: [VIDEO TOPIC]
- Target Length: [MINUTES]
- Channel Niche: [YOUR NICHE]
- Target Audience: [WHO WATCHES]
- Video Goal: [EDUCATE/ENTERTAIN/INSPIRE]
- Call to Action: [WHAT YOU WANT VIEWERS TO DO]

**Generate:**

## üé¨ [VIDEO TITLE OPTIONS]
[3 title options with CTR optimization]

## üñºÔ∏è Thumbnail Concepts
[3 thumbnail ideas]

## üìù Full Script

### HOOK (0:00-0:30)
[Attention-grabbing opening - most important part]

### INTRO (0:30-1:00)
[Channel branding, set expectations]

### MAIN CONTENT
**Section 1: [Topic]** (1:00-X:00)
[Content with retention techniques]

**Section 2: [Topic]** (X:00-X:00)
[Content with pattern interrupts]

**Section 3: [Topic]** (X:00-X:00)
[Content building to climax]

### CLIMAX/PAYOFF
[Deliver on the promise]

### CTA & OUTRO
[Call to action, end screen optimization]

## üìä Retention Strategy
[Techniques used throughout]

## üè∑Ô∏è SEO Elements
- Tags:
- Description:
- Chapters:
prompts.example_output:
## üé¨ VIDEO TITLE OPTIONS

1. **"I Mass Deleted My Emails Using AI (Here's What Happened)"** ‚≠ê RECOMMENDED
   - Curiosity gap + personal story + trending topic (AI)
   
2. **"This AI Deleted 47,000 Emails in 10 Minutes"**
   - Specific number + impressive result + speed
   
3. **"I Let AI Control My Inbox for 30 Days"**
   - Challenge format + timeframe + relatable problem

---

## üñºÔ∏è Thumbnail Concepts

**Concept 1:** Split screen - Left: overwhelmed face with "47,000 EMAILS" text, Right: relieved face with "INBOX ZERO"

**Concept 2:** Screenshot of inbox showing 47,000 unread ‚Üí arrow ‚Üí inbox showing 0, with shocked face overlay

**Concept 3:** Person "pushing" giant email icons into a trash can labeled "AI", exaggerated expression

**Design Notes:**
- High contrast colors (red/blue or yellow/purple)
- Face showing emotion (surprise/relief)
- Large, readable text (3-4 words max)
- Before/after or transformation visual

---

## üìù FULL SCRIPT

### HOOK (0:00-0:30) üé£

**[VISUAL: Screen recording of inbox showing 47,283 unread emails]**

"Forty-seven thousand unread emails.

**[VISUAL: Cut to face, genuine overwhelm]**

That's not a typo. That's my actual inbox. Years of newsletters I never read, receipts I never needed, and reply-all chains that should be illegal.

**[VISUAL: Quick cuts of scrolling through endless emails]**

I tried inbox zero. I tried folders. I tried just... ignoring it. Nothing worked.

**[VISUAL: Cut to face, slight smile]**

So I let an AI delete them. ALL of them. And what happened next genuinely surprised me.

**[VISUAL: Text on screen: "47,283 ‚Üí ???"]**

Stay till the end, because the number it left me with? Not what I expected."

---

### INTRO (0:30-1:15) üì∫

**[VISUAL: Channel logo animation, upbeat music]**

"What's up everyone, I'm [Name], and on this channel we test productivity tools so you don't waste your time on ones that don't work.

**[VISUAL: B-roll of previous videos]**

If you're new here, I've tested over 200 apps, and I only recommend the ones that actually changed how I work.

**[VISUAL: Back to face]**

Today, we're tackling the thing EVERYONE struggles with but nobody talks about: email overwhelm.

**[VISUAL: Stats on screen]**

The average person spends 28% of their workday on email. That's 2.6 hours. Every. Single. Day.

**[VISUAL: Calculator animation]**

Over a career? That's FOUR YEARS of your life in your inbox.

**[VISUAL: Face, direct to camera]**

I'm about to show you how AI can give some of that time back. Let's get into it."

---

### SECTION 1: The Problem (1:15-3:00) üìß

**[VISUAL: Screen share of cluttered inbox]**

"Okay, let's look at the disaster zone.

**[VISUAL: Scrolling through inbox categories]**

I've got:
- 12,000 promotional emails I never opened
- 8,000 social notifications from platforms I don't use anymore
- 15,000 newsletters I subscribed to with good intentions
- And about 10,000 random receipts, confirmations, and 'thanks!' replies

**[VISUAL: Face, slightly embarrassed]**

Look, I'm not proud of this. But I know I'm not alone.

**[VISUAL: Comment screenshots or tweets about email overwhelm]**

I asked on Twitter, and you all sent me YOUR inbox numbers. Some of you have over 100,000 unread. One person had 847,000. HOW.

**[PATTERN INTERRUPT: Quick zoom, sound effect]**

But here's the thing nobody tells you: manually cleaning this is basically impossible.

**[VISUAL: Calculator on screen]**

If I spent 5 seconds per email deciding keep or delete, 47,000 emails would take... 65 HOURS. That's almost two full work weeks.

**[VISUAL: Face, determined]**

So I found another way."

---

### SECTION 2: The Solution (3:00-6:30) ü§ñ

**[VISUAL: Tool interface reveal]**

"Enter [Tool Name]. It's an AI email cleaner that promises to do in minutes what would take me weeks.

**[VISUAL: Signing up process, sped up]**

Setup took about 2 minutes. You connect your Gmail or Outlook, and it starts analyzing.

**[VISUAL: AI scanning animation]**

What it's doing is looking at patterns:
- Emails you never open? Probably safe to delete.
- Senders you always ignore? Unsubscribe.
- Old emails with no replies? Archive.

**[VISUAL: Face, explaining]**

But here's what makes this different from just hitting 'select all, delete'...

**[VISUAL: Tool's categorization screen]**

It CATEGORIZES everything first and lets you review before nuking anything.

**[RETENTION TECHNIQUE: Open loop]**

I'll show you exactly what it found in my inbox in a second, but first, let me explain the settings I used‚Äîbecause this is where most people mess up.

**[VISUAL: Settings walkthrough]**

[Detailed walkthrough of settings, 2 minutes]

**[VISUAL: Finger hovering over 'Clean' button]**

Okay. Moment of truth. I'm about to let AI delete years of emails.

**[VISUAL: Dramatic pause, face showing nervousness]**

Three... two... one...

**[VISUAL: Click, progress bar starts]**
"

---

### SECTION 3: The Results (6:30-9:00) üìä

**[VISUAL: Progress bar completing, satisfying sound effect]**

"It's done. Let's see the damage.

**[VISUAL: Results screen reveal - dramatic music]**

Forty-seven thousand two hundred eighty-three emails...

**[VISUAL: Number counting down animation]**

...became ONE THOUSAND two hundred and twelve.

**[VISUAL: Face, genuine surprise]**

Ninety-seven percent. It deleted ninety-seven percent of my emails.

**[VISUAL: Breakdown pie chart]**

Here's what it removed:
- 15,000 promotional emails (100% gone)
- 12,000 newsletters (kept 3 I actually read)
- 8,000 social notifications (all gone)
- 10,000 old receipts (kept last 90 days)

**[VISUAL: Scrolling through remaining emails]**

And what's left? Actually important stuff. Client emails. Family messages. Things I actually need to respond to.

**[PATTERN INTERRUPT: Record scratch sound]**

But wait. Did it delete anything important?

**[VISUAL: Checking trash/archive]**

I spent 20 minutes going through what it removed. And honestly?

**[VISUAL: Face, impressed]**

It was scary accurate. The only thing I rescued was ONE receipt I might need for taxes. One. Out of 46,000.

**[VISUAL: Before/after inbox comparison]**

Look at this. LOOK AT THIS. This is the same inbox. I can actually SEE my emails now."

---

### SECTION 4: The Unexpected Part (9:00-10:30) üéÅ

**[VISUAL: Face, more reflective tone]**

"Okay, here's the part I didn't expect.

**[VISUAL: B-roll of working at desk, calmer]**

The next morning, I opened my laptop, and for the first time in YEARS, I didn't feel that pit in my stomach when I saw my inbox.

**[VISUAL: Clean inbox on screen]**

Twelve emails. All of them things I could actually respond to.

**[VISUAL: Face, genuine]**

I didn't realize how much mental weight I was carrying from that number. Forty-seven thousand felt like forty-seven thousand tiny tasks I was failing at.

**[VISUAL: Productivity stats if available]**

That week, I responded to emails faster. I missed fewer important messages. I actually hit inbox zero‚ÄîREAL inbox zero‚Äîfor the first time ever.

**[VISUAL: Face, direct to camera]**

This isn't sponsored, by the way. I just genuinely think this solved a problem I'd given up on."

---

### CTA & OUTRO (10:30-11:30) üé¨

**[VISUAL: Tool link on screen]**

"If you want to try it, I put a link in the description. Some of you will clean out 100,000 emails. Please screenshot that and tag me, I need to see it.

**[VISUAL: Face, building energy]**

Now, if you found this helpful, do me a favor‚Äîhit that subscribe button.

**[VISUAL: Subscribe animation]**
